Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Enabling US Early Career Researchers to Advance Polar Science using High Performance Computing and Earth System Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in both high performance computing and scientific understanding are dramatically improving Earth system models. The new processes and capabilities that are being added to Earth system models are leading to new discoveries and improved understanding, especially for polar science and polar prediction capabilities. Continued success in advancing polar research and leveraging of high performance computing resources requires engaging and involving early career polar scientists in today's Earth system modeling and supercomputing frontiers.

In order to train the next generation scientists in polar research and frontiers in high performance computing, a two-week long Polar Modeling Workshop will take place in August 2018. The workshop will support the attendance of about 15 early career polar scientists. All workshop activities will focus on the Community Earth System Model (CESM) and high performance computing supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) at the NCAR-Wyoming Supercomputing Center (WYSC). Workshop participants will gain experience planning, designing, and executing CESM simulations using the NWSC Supercomputing Resources. In the first week, participants would attend the highly successful and well-established CESM tutorial. In the second week, participants would engage in advanced activities focused specifically on capacity building for conducting polar research using the CESM. This 2-week workshop represents a timely opportunity to empower a new generation of polar scientists to use high performance computing and Earth System Modeling in their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to educate early career scientists in today’s polar research and high performance computing frontiers, the PI Jennifer Kay along with collaborators Marika Holland, David Bailey, and Alice DuVivier organized a Polar Modeling Workshop in August 2018. The major goal of this workshop was to empower new generation of polar scientists to use high performance computing and Earth system modeling in their research. To accomplish this goal – workshop participants completed two weeks of training. In the first week, participants attended the highly successful and well-established CESM tutorial.  Successful completion of this first week (or equivalent experience) was required for the second polar-focused week.  In the second week, participants completed advanced activities focused specifically on capacity building for using CESM in polar research. The workshop participants were 20 early career (graduate student, postdoc) polar scientists from 16 US Institutions. The workshop activities were developed and implemented by 8 instructors, 5 of which were also early career (<7 years since Ph.D.). All workshop activities focused on the Community Earth System Model (CESM) and high performance computing supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) at the NCAR-Wyoming Supercomputing Center (NWSC). A major goal for the workshop participants was to gain experience planning, designing, and executing CESM experiments on the NWSC Supercomputing Resources.  The workshop was a big success.  Sample feedback from the participants said:  “This was a great workshop and I would high recommend to the NSF to help fund it once again.”; “You were all amazing to meet and learn from! This was a great workshop and it exceeded my expectations!”; “As I am just starting grad school this experience will be extremely valuable as I get further into the world of modelling research”; “I have absolutely no doubt that this workshop will prove invaluable over the next 5 years.”; “I've learned more the past week than in my first year of grad school.”
